title: 107_hr3176
content: The Act titled "Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act" establishes protocols for national responses to public health emergencies involving dangerous biological agents or chemicals. The Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to develop protocols for responding to public health emergencies involving dangerous biological agents or chemicals. The Secretary must consult with states and define hazardous agents as dangerous biological agents and chemicals. The Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act defines "hazardous agents" as dangerous biological agents and chemicals. Dangerous biological agents are those listed under the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996, while dangerous chemicals will be listed by the Secretary in consultation with the Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board. The Secretary, in consultation with the Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board, will develop a list of chemicals known to cause serious harm to human health. Protocols specific to each hazardous agent will be created under this Act. The Secretary will develop protocols for hazardous agents known to cause harm to human health, with specific provisions for each agent. Priorities will be established within 45 days of the Act's enactment, with protocols to be completed within 45 days of development for the highest priority agent. The Secretary will develop protocols for hazardous agents, ensuring uniformity in public health emergencies and coordinating with response personnel to provide timely information to individuals at sites. The Secretary will develop protocols for hazardous agents in public health emergencies, coordinating with response personnel to provide timely information and treatment, decontaminating sites, and adapting responses based on the nature of the agent release. Periodic reviews and exemptions are also part of the protocol development process. The Secretary will periodically review and revise protocols for hazardous agents in public health emergencies. Development exemptions may be granted if existing protocols meet requirements. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2002 through 2006. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2002 through 2006 to carry out the review and revision requirements under subsection (f).
